Journal.Title: Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association (1995)

Article.ArticleTitle: Historic PM<sub>2.5</sub>/PM<sub>10</sub> Concentrations in the Southeastern United States-Potential Implications of the Revised Particulate Matter Standard.

AbstractText: This report summarizes a PM<sub>2.5</sub>/PM<sub>10</sub> particulate matter data set consisting of 861 PM<sub>2.5</sub>/PM<sub>10</sub> sample pairs collected with dichotomous samplers by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) from 1982 to 1991. Eight monitoring stations, ranging from urban-industrial to rural-background, were operated across three east-central U.S. states. Annual average PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentrations ranged from 12.6 to 21.3 micrograms per cubic meter (μg/m<sup>3</sup>), with an overall mean of 15.7 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. Likewise, annual average PM<sub>10</sub> concentrations ranged from 17.8 to 33.7 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, with an overall mean of 23.7 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. High summer-low winter seasonality was evident, particularly for PM<sub>2.5</sub>, with the highest monthly PM<sub>2.5</sub> and PM<sub>10</sub> concentrations in August (26.4 and 37.5 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, respectively) and the lowest in February (9.9 and 15.3 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, respectively). A strong association (r<sup>2</sup> = 0.84) was found between PM and PM mass with PM mass contributing, on average, 67% of PM<sub>10</sub> mass. Applying TVA's PM<sub>2 5</sub>/PM<sub>10</sub> ratio to recent (1993-1995) regional high-volume PM<sub>10</sub> Aerometric Information Retrieval System (AIRS) data for the east-central United States suggests that as many as 80% of monitored counties would have equaled or exceeded the level of the new annual PM<sub>2.5</sub> metric of 15 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. A decline in average PM<sub>2.5</sub> mass on the order of 3-5 μg/m<sup>3</sup> from 1982 through 1991 is also suggested. Daily PM<sub>2 5</sub> mass appears to be reasonably well associated (r = 0.47) with maximum hourly ozone during the warmer months (spring through fall). Sulfate compounds comprise a major portion of the measured PM<sub>2 5</sub> mass, with that fraction being highest in the summer months. Viewed collectively, these data suggest that although compliance with the annual and 24-hr PM and 24-hr PM metrics should prove readily attainable, the annual PM<sub>2.5</sub> metric will present a major regulatory management challenge for much of the east-central United States.
